column1: Blacktown City Council is a local government area in Western Sydney
column3: approximately 35 kilometres (22 mi) west of the Sydney central business district
column4: in the state of New South Wales
column5: Australia. Established in 1906 as the Blacktown Shire and becoming the Municipality of Blacktown in 1961 before gaining city status in 1979
column6: the City occupies an area of 246.9 square kilometres (95.3 sq mi) and has a population of 366
column8: making it the second most populous local government area in Sydney.The Mayor of the Blacktown City Council is Cr. Tony Bleasdale
column10: a member of the Australian Labor Party
column11: who was elected on 9 October 2019 following the resignation of Stephen Bali

column1: The first road from Prospect to Richmond became known as the "Black Town Road" and in 1860 the Railway Department gave the name of "Black Town Road Station" to the railway station at the junction of the railway and the Black Town Road
column2: with the name shortening to "Blacktown" by 1862. The Blacktown area was first incorporated on 6 March 1906 as the "Shire of Blacktown" alongside 132 other new shires across the state as a result of the passing of the Local Government (Shires) Act
column3: 1905. The first five-member temporary council was appointed on 15 May 1906 and first met on 20 June in the Rooty Hill School of Arts. The Blacktown Shire became the "Municipality of Blacktown" on 17 June 1961 and was granted city status on 9 March 1979

column1: The City of Blacktown has a number of heritage-listed sites
column2: including those on the New South Wales State Heritage Register:
Great Western Highway: Veteran Hall Remains
Ponds Road: St Bartholomew's Anglican Church and Cemetery
Reservoir Road: Former Great Western Road Alignment
East of Reservoir: Prospect Reservoir Valve House
385 Reservoir Road: Royal Cricketers Arms Inn

column3: 962 people resident in the Blacktown local government area
column4: of these 49.7 per cent were male and 50.3 per cent were female. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people made up 2.8 per cent of the population
column5: which was slightly higher than the NSW and Australian averages of 2.9 and 2.8 per cent respectively. The median age of people in the City of Blacktown was 33 years
column6: which was significantly lower than the national median of 38 years. Children aged 0 â€“ 14 years made up 22.8 per cent of the population and people aged 65 years and over made up 9.0%10.3 per cent of the population. Of people in the area aged 15 years and over
column7: 52.3 per cent were married and 9.9 per cent were either divorced or separated.Population growth in the City of Blacktown between the 2001 census and the 2006 census was 6.47 per cent; and in the subsequent five years to the 2011 census
column8: population growth was 10.82 per cent. At the 2016 census
column9: the population in the local government area increased by 11.91 per cent. When compared with total population growth of Australia for the same period
column11: population growth in Blacktown local government area was in excess of 35% more than the national average. The median weekly income for residents within the City of Blacktown was generally on par with the national average.At the 2016 census
column12: the proportion of residents in the Blacktown local government area who stated their ancestry as Filipino
column13: was in excess of six times the national average. The proportion of residents who stated a religious affiliation with Hinduism was in excess of three times the national average; the proportion of Catholics was 33 per cent above the national average; and the proportion of residents with no religion about half the national average. column1: Blacktown City Council is composed of fifteen Councillors elected proportionally as five separate wards
column2: each electing three Councillors. All Councillors are elected for a fixed four-year term of office. The Mayor is elected by the Councillors at the first meeting of the Council and since 2016 has served a two-year term. The Mayor from 2014 to 2019
column3: Stephen Bali was required to stand down from Council as a Mayor and Councillor by October 2019
column4: due to the Local Government Amendment (Members of Parliament) Act
column5: 2012 which requires state members of parliament to relinquish local government offices no more than two years after their election. With Bali's resignation on 9 October 2019
column6: Cr Tony Bleasdale was elected Mayor.The most recent election was held on 10 September 2016
